body:
Comment 4 by **cmelliso**: 
I listed above (readout 2) what happens under the normal windows command prompt, but I
will do it again in more detail.

>dir
...
10/19/2013  10:15 AM    <DIR>          .
10/19/2013  10:15 AM    <DIR>          ..
10/19/2013  09:51 AM                 0 bady.y
               1 File(s)              0 bytes
               2 Dir(s)  489,959,792,640 bytes free

>go tool yacc bady.y

>dir
...
10/19/2013  10:16 AM    <DIR>          .
10/19/2013  10:16 AM    <DIR>          ..
10/19/2013  09:51 AM                 0 bady.y
10/19/2013  10:16 AM                 0 y.go
10/19/2013  10:16 AM               248 y.output
               3 File(s)            248 bytes
               2 Dir(s)  489,959,792,640 bytes free

Notice there is no error message printed to the screen, even though the program runs,
but fails.

In all cases, the actual go executable is coming straight from the windows installation
(go1.1.2.windows-386.msi).  I was only changing the shell from cmd.exe to bash.  I am
NOT running go compiled with cygwin, I am running go as distributed for windows.
